questions.text: Which of the following transports are hormone-regulated?

options.text: Na+ reabsorption in the proximal tubule - aldosterone
K+ reabsorption in the distal tubule - aldosterone
K+ secretion in the collecting duct - aldosterone
K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending segment - vasopressin
Na+ reabsorption in the collecting duct - aldosterone
Ca2+-reabsorption in the distal tubule - PTH

metadata.matchReason: Topic 57: 'Which transport is under hormonal control?' - aldosterone regulates Na+ channels and K+ secretion in collecting duct; PTH regulates Ca2+ in distal tubule

options.text: daily urine production may exceed 14-15 liters
also known as diabetes mellitus
usually caused by elevated blood AVP (ADH) levels
may cause hyperhydration (water intoxication)
usually presents with glycosuria

metadata.matchReason: Topic 57: 'Identify the tubular segment where water permeability is under hormonal control' - lack of ADH causes massive water loss in diabetes insipidus

questions.text: What is the source of ammonium ions secreted by the renal tubuli?

options.text: amine groups of glutamine
side chain amine groups of basic amino acids (arginine, lysine)
amino groups from urea reabsorbed in the tubuli
ammonium ions circulating in the blood plasma

metadata.matchReason: Topic 57: Renal ammonium production from glutamine metabolism in proximal tubule cells

questions.text: Which statement is true concerning Ca reabsorption in the kidney?

options.text: Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the distal tubule
There is an active Ca reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the collecting ducts
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the Loop of Henle
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the proximal tubule
There is an active Ca reabsorption in the distal tubule

metadata.matchReason: Topic 57: PTH enhances Ca2+ reabsorption in distal tubule; active Ca2+ transport occurs in both proximal and distal tubules

questions.text: A substance which is freely filtered, secreted and not reabsorbed in the tubular system has a clearance:

options.text: lower than urea
higher than inulin
the same as inulin
the same as urea
higher than urea
lower than inulin

metadata.matchReason: Topic 55: 'How much is the clearance of a freely filtrated X substance if...there is a net tubular secretion' - clearance > GFR (inulin) and > urea clearance

questions.text: The parasympathetic preganglionic neuronal cell bodies controlling the detrusor muscle of the bladder are located in the

options.text: hypothalamus
medulla oblongata
lumbar spinal cord
sacral spinal cord

metadata.matchReason: Topic 58: 'Explain the visceral sensory, autonomic (sympathetic and parasympathetic) and somatic motor innervation of the urinary bladder' - parasympathetic from sacral segments S2-S4

questions.text: Which tubular segment is the action site of furosemide type diuretics inhibiting the Na+K+2Cl- transporter?

options.text: collecting duct
proximal convoluted tubule
thick ascending segment of the loop of Henle
distal convoluted tubule

metadata.matchReason: Topic 57: 'Identify the targets of the following diuretics...loop diuretics (furosemide)' - acts on Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in thick ascending limb

questions.text: During moderate exercise, diastolic arterial pressure may not change significantly from that during rest, although cardiac output increases. This is the result of the

options.text: decreased total peripheral resistance
decreased arteriolar flow during diastole
increased stroke volume
increased heart rate

stimulates aldosterone secretion
is released in response to hypervolemia

causes vasoconstriction in the renal artery
is released in response to hypovolemia
